subNodes.conversationText: A scruffy young man with sunken eyes was sitting just off the young witch's path. He was resting his right elbow on a nearby boulder and supporting his head with his hand, the very picture of dejection. A shepherd's crook leaned against the boulder too.
"Greetings, traveler," the shepherd said, wiping his eyes. "I didn't expect to see anyone else here. What are you? Wastrel, fairy, thief?"
"Well, I hope you don't mean me any harm. I don't have much to offer."
"You're a shepherd. What are you doing here? We're miles from any pastureland."
"Sheep? How did they end up here?"
The shepherd laughed bitterly at this. "Do you?"
"I watch... watched...  the sheep of a ruthless, exacting master. I grew up poor, you see; my parents were feeble, and I had no siblings. Desperate, I hired myself out to him."
"Work was hard. His sheep grazed on the slopes of a great volcano that spat void instead of fire. They were stupid creatures and always got too close."
[Natural Philosophy] "A volcano? You come from very far away, I take it."

"The slopes are covered with the blackest loam, and the grass is so green that you'd weep to see it. The grapes are redder than blood, and the bees produce a honey that makes sugar taste like sand. But the inside of the volcano, nothing itself, is like nothing I can describe."

"He sent me to fetch this calendar from the ruins of the great library of Xianaqash. How he knew about it or was so sure I'd find it exactly where he told me it'd be I have no idea. I have learned not to pry too deeply into his mysteries." The man peered at the page inquisitively, first right-side up and then upside-down.

"If you say so." It looked like a page from an old calendar. At the top was written "Januarie, Month of the Beggar." Below the writing was an image. A beggar was trying to run through twilight and deep snow while three skinny wolves pulled at his cloak. A candle glowed in the window of a far-off house, but the door was locked, knew. The old woman who lived there was deaf and suspicious. Her window's light seemed as remote as the cold stars above the scene.
"Go on -- but the imitations are not necessary."
"The fairy grabbed the calendar. 'Don't take that,' I said. 'It's a present!' They seemed very childlike, so I thought this line of reasoning might persuade them."
"Indeed. 'All the more reason to take it,' the fairy said. "You take your present as you get it."
"'Time! So that's what this is. What's to be done with it?"

"'The only thing you can." At that, the lead fairy threw the calendar into the air. 

"Waste it!"

A great gust of wind, quite extraordinary, leapt up out of nowhere, ripping the calendar apart and sending the leaves flying in every direction.  Then the fairies turned into moths and flew away."

"What am I to do? The manuscript is -- was -- quite precious. My master will be sorely disappointed that all I have is January. But how can I find the rest? I can't spend days scouring perilous woods."
"That is exactly what I'm doing. I could keep an eye open for the rest of your calendar."

"Well, a friend of mine lives not far from the forest. I can stay with him for a few days and come back. If you find at least six of the lost pages, I'll give you something from my master's collection that might suit you." He looked meaningfully at Pharaoh. "I'm not a churchy sort of person. I don't mind helping witches."

They soon came to an agreement. Colin -- that was his name -- would wait at the forest gate next Thursday. "You know, the south entrance, where the trail leads to the road. The one with the old statue on the south edge of the woods," he told <FirstName>.

Then the two parted ways.

actions.a_parameter_1: THE ELEVEN MONTHS has been added to journal.

subNodes.conversationText: "'Void instead of fire'? I don't really understand."

"No... One day it was very hot. The sheep were lazy, and so was I; I used to sit under a gum tree and sing songs when the weather was too warm, and I was in the middle of singing when I noticed an old woman listening."
"I greeted her and asked her to sit in the shade with me. But she shook her head and told me she had a bag full of wind and needed no shade."
"On first acquaintance he seemed kindness itself, generosity in the flesh. But I soon learned that he took more than he gave."
"Work was hard. His sheep grazed on the slopes of a great volcano that spat void instead of fire. They were stupid creatures and always got too close."
"You don't seem to be looking for them at the moment," observed the young witch.
"No, I've all but given up. It's a long story."
"It's a long story, and you have other business."
"None of those things, which is all you need to know for now."
"Well, I hope you don't mean me any harm. I don't have much to offer."
"Well, I hope you don't mean me any harm. I don't have much to offer."
